item.title: Resume
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
p: 503-962-9521
e: Taylor.A.Huston@Gmail.com
Open to Unpaid Part-Time Internships, Paid Full-Time Internships or other Entry-Level Positions.

Education

University of Advancing Technology

B.S. in Computer Science Auditing, Fall 2015 As an alumni I am able to audit classes for free. I am auditing my way through their C.S. degree. I amcurrently taking the last few senior level classes (online) and I expect to be 'done' by this fall. Courses include: C++ and Java Syntax, Software Design Methodology, Data Structures and Algorithms, Compilers, and Operating Systems. B.A. in Game Design 3.35 GPA, Fall 2010 A primarily art and theory based degree. A fun, though if in retrospect) not the most practical of degrees, Courses include: Game Design Theory, Level Design Theory, and some 2D Art and 3D Animation classes.

MOOCs and Self Study

Coursera
  • Algorithms (Princeton)
  • Android Development Specialization (In Progress)
Udacity
  • JavaScript Basics
  • Intro To jQuery
  • Object Orientated JavaScript
  • How to use Git and Github
Other
  • Codecademy
  • Treehouse
  • Codeschool
  • The Odin Project
  • RubyMonk

Skills

Competent In - Things I've spent a decent amount of time studying.
  • C++
  • Java
  • Ruby
  • HTML5
  • CSS3
  • JavaScript
  • jQuery
Dabbled In - Things I've had at some basic exposure to and would love an opportunity to learn more about.
  • Angular
  • Node
  • Express
  • MongoDB
  • Rails
  • Android Development

Experience

Sites, LLC

Customer Supper/Front End Developer Dec 2010 - Current Since graduating with my first B.A. I have been working at TherapySites providing customer support and custom design work for our in-house CMS. Recently I have been trying to move my way into more of a developer position and I am currently the lead designer on our new set of fully responsive templates.

Projects

Responsive Templates

I am currently in charge of creating new versions of our existing templates in order to make them fully responsive. Previously none of our templates were mobile friendly. Additionally each template had it's own completely unique (usually table-based) HTML structure, which made making custom changes to customer websites inconsistent and difficult. I have rewritten them to all be based off the same table-less HTML structure with the layout/design entirely CSS and JavaScript based. I am also designing them to be flexible enough that we can start releasing entirely new templates using the same HTML structure on a regular basis.

Will Code For Food

WillCodeForFood.io. My idea for a small job website entirely for internships, apprenticeships and entry-level developer positions. Currently Wordpress based, though I am planning on building a custom solution for it as a learning exercise.

More Coming Soon!

Working full time during the day and auditing classes at night hasn't left much time for large, non-academic personal projects. This is something I hope to change over the next few weeks.

item.title: Photography
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: Photography has become a recent hobby of mine, and as soon as I get done sorting through all of the pictures I have taken in the last year and a half since I got my Nikon D5000, and picking out my favorites (out of close to 15,000 pictures) I will be throwing them up here! Stay tuned.

item.title: Great Actors Who Make Horrible Films
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: This is my ever expanding list of actors who I believe are truly talented, but make horrible movies.  And I don't mean the occasional bad flick, I mean consistently make horrible movie over and over and over again. Will Ferell Fantastic actor, from great comedy like his run on SNL and films such as Anchorman to more serious roles like Everything Must Go and Stranger Then Fiction (one of my favorite films).  Makes horrible films, like Kicking and Screaming, Semi-Pro, Blades of Glory, etc. Robert De Niro De Niro used to be one of the most respected actors in Hollywood with a film career that spanned decades and included some incredibly iconic roles.  But, especially in the last 10 years or so, for there seems to be more and more roles he just took for the money.  There has been a few gems, like Stardust which, even if you don't like that movie you have to admit he did a great job, his career has either been bad sequels (Meet the Fockers, Analyze That) or bad dramas where he just seemed to phone in his lines.  Showtime, Righteous Kill, 15 Minutes. Nicolas Cage Nicolas Cage is a great actor.  Even in a bad role in a bad film, you can see that he has talent to spare.  But it just seems like he will take any script shoved in front of him.  He's like the popular guy in High School that could have his pick of women, but that doesn't stop him from getting drunk and sleeping with  anything that moves on a weekly basis. Eddie Murphy Probably the biggest offender of this crime.  Great actor, as seen by everything before the first Nutty Professor.  Makes HORRIBLE films, as seen by everything after the first Nutty Professor.  Just absolutely dog shit films. I mean, come on, Norbit?  My only theory can be is that sometime during the filming of Nutty Professor he was replaced by an alien pod version of himself.

item.title: CS Curriculum
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
Like I stated in my blog, while I am technically auditing my way through my Alma Mater's CS degree, I am basically teaching myself. While UAT may not have been the best at teaching me what I needed to know, it at least told me what things and in what order I needed to teach myself. Which, really, with the way the internet is, everything you need to know about CS can be found completely free online. So in that spirit I've decided to outline a general curriculum of (mostly) free resources (not counting textbooks you may want to get) that anyone can use to teach themselves CS. Resources:
  • Berkeley Webcasts - I wish I had found out about this sooner. They are putting full, up to date videos of a lot of their classes online for free. And in many cases the classes have accompanying websites that have all of the homework, midterms and finals, all with solutions. You can even start watching them the first day of a new semester and follow right along with the students like you were in class.
  • MIT OCW - MIT has a lot of archived courses online. The information is good (it is from MIT) but the quality of the courses is hit or miss. And by that I mean some have full video lectures and everything, while others may just be slides. Also the course numbering is a little inconsistent as well, so it can be a little confusing as to which course to do "next". I've only mentioned courses that include video lectures. Most have assignments and exams with solutions.
  • Coursera - Coursera has a lot of Computer Science related classes, and are adding more and more all the time. They aren't self paced, so you have to be vigilant about watching for when classes start and sign up in time, but most of the important classes (the ones I mention here) seem to re-run at regular intervals so that shouldn't be too much of an issue. Some of the classes offer the ability to pay a small fee and get a verified certificate of completion, if that matters to you.
  • edX - EDx has a few CS related classes. It doesn't seem to have as many as Coursera and they don't re-run as often (this of course may change) but there still seems to be some good classes in there that you might want to take if you have the time. They are also introducing their 'xSeries' sequences which, similar to some Coursera Specializations, you can pay a small fee and get a verified certificate of completion. As of writing this they seem to be piloting a 'Foundations of Computer Science' certificate (I say piloting since only the first two classes have been released, with the latter scheduled over the course of the next year).
  • Khan Academy - While they've actually recently introduced some CS related courses, they don't seem to be very in-depth, more of a light introduction. That may change in the future. But regardless when it comes to math it's a GREAT resource.
  • Safari Books Online - If you're more of a reader, for a relatively low monthly fee you can subscribe to this service and just read a good book on all of the subjects you need to know.
Basic Syntax: To get started you need to understand the basic concepts of writing code. Most of these classes will all cover the bases you need to know. By the time you are done the general idea is to understand the following concepts in at least one programming language: Variables, Basic Input and Output, Loops and Conditionals, Classes, Inheritance and Object-Orientated Programming Concepts, and basic Data Structures (at least Arrays and Linked Lists).
  • Berkeley Webcasts - CS61A, 61B, 61C. Berkeley's year long 3 course introduction to CS. From the official course introduction "The CS 61 series is an introduction to computer science, with particular emphasis on software and on machines from a programmer's point of view. This first course concentrates mostly on the idea of abstraction, allowing the programmer to think in terms appropriate to the problem rather than in low-level operations dictated by the computer hardware. The next course, CS 61B, will deal with the more advanced engineering aspects of software, such as constructing and analyzing large programs. Finally, CS 61C concentrates on machines and how they carry out the programs you write." Looks like it starts with Python and goes through Data Structures in Java, so thoroughly covers EVERYTHING you need to know to get started. I haven't taken them yet, but being that it's from Berkeley I am assuming it's high quality stuff. Look for the latest offerings on Berkeley Webcasts.
  • Foundations of Computer Science xSeries from MITx - Since this is based off of MIT classes, it's also probably a good place to start. Like I said it seems to be in a pilot phase. As of writing this enrollment for the first class is closed, and I have no idea when it will start up again, but it may be worth keeping an eye on. Also, unlike the other suggestions in this section, this one has the ability to pay for verified certificates of completion, if that's important to you.
  • Harvard CS50 - This is a very well regarded introductory CS class. Since it's only one course I don't know how in depth it goes, but it's probably a good place to get your feet wet. You can take it self paced anytime through edX or the class website.
  • MIT OCW. 6.00 and 6.01 also look to be a good introduction to CS using Python.
  • Programming in Java - This book, along with it's associated booksite, is a great and thorough introduction to programming and CS concepts. It also has several followup books that I will mention later.
Calculus: Technically you don't NEED to know Calculus to be a developer. You can probably get away with just High School Algebra. But if you want to be a good developer, the more math you know the better.
  • Khan Academy has a great sequence of all the things in Calculus. It also has plenty of Precalculus and Trig information if you need a refresher.
  • Coursera has a self-paced Calculus course you can take anytime, which mainly pulls from Ohio State Calculus One. They also periodically have a more advanced Single Variable Calculus course you can take that has the option of paying for a verified certificate. Looks to be intended more for people who have already been exposed to Calculus at the High School level.
  • MIT OCW has full classes on Single-Variable and Multi-Variable Calculus.
Discrete Math: Discrete math is a tricky subject. It's definitely important to a CS student, though more so than any other class it seems to vary. From the few curriculums I have seen, every college is different. Sometimes it's a stand-alone class (or two) you take your first year, other times it's just rolled into an Algorithms class you take as a Junior. But regardless, while you don't have to be an expert (most of the courses on the subject seem to have very generous grading policies), having a good understanding of the concepts will help you a great deal down the road.
  • Berkely Webcasts - CS70. Berkely's Discrete Math and Probability course. The natural successor to the 61x sequence from above. It's what I used to learn it (UAT does not have a Discrete Math class as part of their curriculum) and I can attest that it is really well done.
  • MIT OCW - Mathematics for Computer Science. I haven't taken this class, but at first glance it seems very thorough.
  • Khan Academy - While they don't have a Discrete Math class specifically, you can cherry pick videos from other classes to reinforce some of the Discrete Math concepts. Specifically their probability and sequences playlists are good review.
Algorithms: Your bread and butter. The most important thing you need to master to be a good developer.
  • Berkely Webcasts - CS170. Berkeley's Algorithms class. I haven't taken it yet, but I probably will at some point.
  • Coursera Princeton - Runs very frequently and serves as a great introductory course. Very implementation based. Goes over all of the needed Data Structures as well. Doesn't require a lot of math or complicated analysis. It's also taught by the same instructor as the Programming in Java. It's the natural followup to that book (though really anyone with any background in Java can take the course). It also has a great textbook and an associated booksite. Pretty much all of the resources you need to really to get a good grasp of the concept. I found it to be much more instructive than UAT's Algorithms class. Additionally it has two followup classes, that also have associated textbooks from the same author, if you're so inclined (though they are more math heavy, should be taken after you've learned Calculus and Discrete Math). Also (Unlike the first book in this 'series' for some reason) these three textbooks are all available through Safari Books Online.
  • Coursera Stanford - Stanford also sponsors an Algorithms class on Coursera. This one is language agnostic and definitely more theory/math based. An interesting class, but one you should wait to take until after Calculus and Discrete Math. It uses the classic textbook CLRS. A thorough, if a bit intimidating, textbook that every Computer Scientist should read through at some point in there careers.
  • MIT OCW - Their introductory Algorithms class. Uses Python and is a good followup to the other MIT OCW courses I've mentioned so far.
Operating Systems: Coming soon.   Compilers: Coming soon.   Databases: Coming soon.   Electives: Coming soon.

item.title: What Makes a Movie Good?
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
Hackers

Hackers is my favorite movie. It isn't a good movie by any typical measure of what makes a movie great. It's acting doesn't particularly stand out. The story is entertaining but by no means revolutionary. It does have a fantastic soundtrack, but by most typical definitions it is an above average film at best. Yet I can watch it over and over and over again and never not be entertained

What defines a good movie?

What does one define as a good movie anyway? Normally when you ask this question you get some response relating to good acting or directing or cinematography. Which are all good things, but is that really what makes a movie good?

Movies are a source of entertainment

At their core, films are supposed to entertain people. So wouldn't this mean that the movie that entertains the most amount of people the most amount of times is the best? I bring this up because I have realized that there are many films that are considered great movies. Classics even. But they are also the kind of movie that most people only watch once, maybe twice in their entire lifetime. The Citizen Kane's and Schindler's Lists of the film world. Ask anyone and 90% of people will tell you that these movies are classics, films that should be revered for all time. Yet ask those same people whether they would like to watch one of those movies or some action movie filled with cool special effects and lots of 'splosions, most people are going to choose the action movie. They 'know' Citizen Kane is a better film, but they will still choose the movie with 19 unnecessary car chases in it. So by this definition, is the action film a 'better' movie then the revered classic? I 'know' that 12 Angry Men is better then the new Tron, but guess which one I queue up on Netflix when I feel like being entertained for an hour or so? A lot of 'classic' movies just aren't that fun to watch more then once. Once you know how they end, the appeal is gone.

Movies are supposed to make money

The film business is just that, a business. Businesses, at their core, are out to make money. There are many movies the receive massive critical acclaim that like 19 normal people actually go see in the theaters. Then you have Transformers 3, which was absolute dog shit, and it makes a bazillion dollars in the theaters. It will make that much again from DVD sales, Netflix rentals, etc. Meanwhile the artsy, critically acclaimed film that is considered a 'better' film will be largely forgotten after a few weeks by all but the most devoted movie buffs. So if you look at it from a financial standpoint, Transformers 3 should be considered one of the greatest films of all time.

Movies that hit all the right spots

Occasionally there is a movie that receives massive critical acclaim, can be watched over and over again without getting boring, and make a buttload of money. Avatar, Titanic, Toy Story 3. But in the grand scheme of things these movies are relatively rare. So I ask again: What makes a movie good?

item.title: Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: So I am ridiculously excited for Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning.  It has a stellar team behind it, the early reviews look really promising, but what I am most excited about is that the storyline is being written by R.A. Salvatore.  Salvatore is a New York Times bestselling author, so I am sure most of you have came across his books at one time or another.  But if you haven't you should.  Go to the bookstore now and buy The Crystal Shard.  Go on.  Right now.  I'll wait. I got a used copy of The Crystal Shard when I was like 8, I think, and it completely opened my eyes and ignited my love of fantasy novels.  And all of his other books have been equally fantastic.  So a AAA game written by him is basically my wet dream.  And it's not like he just penned a quick story-line overview in a notebook for the design team.  He has supposedly laid out of 10,000 years of history and lore for this world (probably to leave things open for sequels, prequels, etc).  The project eventually started out as an MMO, and even though it is now a single-player RPG there is still rumored to be an MMO based on it in the works...so yeah...social lives are overrated anyways. Anyways, check out this interview with the producer of the game and bask in it's awesomeness.

item.title: Yeah I know
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
I need to update this more. I'm a busy man! Stop bothering me.
Still on track to start at PSU. Not officially enrolled in any classes at the moment, self studying, have to take some finals as 'placement' tests over the next few weeks. They are making me jump through a lot of hoops, but it will be worth it in the long run.
Still debating on buying a condo/townhome or not. I was pre-approved for more then enough, and I make enough to afford it, but do I want that kind of commitment? I don't even like signing a cell phone contract. Plus, for the amount of money I was pre-approved for I can either get a 1 bedroom place downtown close to campus, which would be nice, but I would probably sell it in two years after I graduate with my Masters, so taking that into consideration, would it even be worth it when I can still get a 1 bedroom apartment close to campus for several hundred a month cheaper? On the other hand, for the same amount of money I can get a 3 bedroom with a garage and a backyard, but then I would have to live in the suburbs, and juggling work and school will be significantly easier when I have a 5 minute bike ride to class as opposed to a 30 minute drive, plus dealing with parking and all that jazz. Decisions decisions.
I promise I will get my photos sorted, edited and uploaded this weekend, and by promise I mean I might do it if there's nothing good on tv.
Enjoy your weekend everyone!

item.title: Born This Way
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: When I was a kid in a small fishing village in Alaska. Had never been exposed to politics or anything even remotely close to it. One day, I couldn't have been older to 9 or 10, Jeff Wheaton was teaching us about the basics of economics, and one of the first things we were taught was about how there has to be a set amount of money for an economy to work. After all, if your print an infinite amount of of money, then money becomes worthless. I remember thinking that "wait, if there is only so much money to go around, and all of the rich people have it, then there isn't enough left over for the rest and that's why there is poor people."  Simple math, even to a child. I was also hooked on the Captain Planet cartoons. When I was a kid I used to get angry at cars that had dual exhaust pipes because, in my mind, 2x exhaust pipes = 2x the pollution. Makes sense when your 7. I remember watching movies where gays and lesbians were discriminated against or ridiculed, and legitimately thinking that "that only happens in movies now, not in real life". The fact that it was even still an issue never crossed my mind. Every one of the above statements is true. Not making any of it up or exaggerating. The fact is, I was a liberal years before I even understood the concept of what a liberal was. I was literally born this way.

item.title: The Crabapple Trees Are Dying
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
Christmas is my favorite time of year. Always has been. And not because of presents (not that presents aren't awesome) but because of the memories.
We used to always have Christmas at my grandparent's (mother's side) house in Wasilla, AK. It's a nice house on a gorgeous 40-acre property. My grandpa got it when it was nothing but trees, cleared it, made a runway for his airplane (he was a bush pilot). By the time he was done it had two houses, a greenhouse, a barn and an airplane hanger. It is my favorite place in the world. Because of the memories. My mom married and divorced twice, we moved around a bit, but we always had 'The Homestead' as we called it.
I have so many fond childhood memories of that place. In the winter my grandpa used to use his tractor to pile up all the snow from the property into a big hill and we would turn it into the best snow fort ever. In the summer my cousin and I would spend hours 4-wheeling in the trails behind the house. We would go hang out at this mystery tree fort we found in the woods. No idea who built it but it's always been there. Not even a little bit safe, but we didn't care. When I got older there is a pond back there that I may or may not have taken a few girls to for skinny dipping. But out of all those memories my favorite was always Christmas.
My grandma and aunt would cook for days. We would have a ridiculous amount of people crammed into the house. Family. Friends of family. Friends of family's children. Big ol' Christmas tree in the living room surrounded by a sea of presents. Presents as far as the eye can see. It was epic. And we don't do it anymore and I can't begin to explain how sad that makes me.
Which brings me to my point. The crabapple trees are dying. When I was a kid my grandpa planted three crapabble trees in the yard and I watched them grow my entire life. They grew with my sister and I. We are the youngest two of six grandkids, and the only ones to ever actually live on the property. We lived there for a while after my mom divorced my dad when I was three, and then we moved back after she divorced her third husband when I was 14, and lived there ever since. When I came back to visit for the holidays this time I was shocked to see that one of the trees had died and already been cut down, and the other two won't make it to next season.
I think it all started when my grandpa passed away. A few years later my grandma bought a small house in town so it would be easier for her to get around and for her friends to come over. All of my older cousins grew up, got married, started families of their own, moved away, etc. Every year Christmas became smaller and smaller. Now we have it at my aunt's house and it's not nearly as big as it used to be. This year my sister worked on Christmas Eve and we went and bugged her instead of even going to my aunt's for dinner. We did stop by to say hi later, but only for a minute. It just wasn't the same.
I understand that that's life. Things change. People move on. And normally that doesn't bother me, but every year that we don't have Christmas on The Homestead like we used to get I get a little sad inside. The crabapple trees are dying, and in a way it feels like my childhood is dying with them.

item.title: Resolutions
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
Here are my cliché New Years resolutions for this year
  • Write at least 2 posts here each week.
  • Write some code every day.
  • Stick to my vegan diet.
  • Ride my bike every day, try to increase total miles ridden in a week every week.
  • Get back down to 145lb, where I was last summer before a semester of stress eating (and then my mom's holiday baked goods) took their toll.
  • Re-learn Japanese, then French
  • Volunteer a MINIMUM of once a month, more if I can.
Totally do-able, right?

item.title: Why I won't be buying an Xbox One, or a PS4 for that matter.
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: So earlier this month Microsoft officially revealed the Xbox one and the internet rose up and gave a collective 'meh'.  To say that response to the reveal has been lukewarm would be being too kind. I consider myself a gamer.  I spent my childhood glued to my NES and SNES.  I spent my teenage years glued to my N64 and PS1.  I have owned every Nintendo home console, every Sega console starting with the Genesis, and all three Playstations.  I still have my Dreamcast hooked up.  I still play my old Ps1 RPGs (probably my favorite games) when I get bored.  I am a gamer.  And I have no interest in the next generation of gaming consoles.  Don't get my wrong, the tech specs of the next Xbox are very impressive.  I'm sure the PS4 will be even more powerful.  State of the art...for about 6 months, and therein lies the problem. In addition to being a console gamer I have also always been a PC gamer.  For most of my life those have been two separate entities.  PC was for my keyboard and mouse strategy games and my FPSs.  My Warcrafts, Diablos and Quakes.  Consoles were for my twitch reflex adventure games.  My Sonic the Hedgehogs and Metroid Primes.  But over the last few years that has changed and the two worlds have definitely merged. To clarify, for the purpose of this article when I say console I am going to be referring to then 'hardcore' consoles, the Playstations and the Xboxs (Xboxes?).  It still sounds strange not including Nintendo in with the 'real' consoles, but that's how it feels nowadays, Nintendo does their own thing, which I will bring up later on in this post. But getting back to the point, nowadays most games are released for the Xbox 360, PS3 and the PC.  Not only are they released for all 3, but they look better on my PC.  Plain and simple.  Except for maybe a very brief period of time after a new console is released, my PC will always have better hardware and better graphics.  If a game is released for a console and the PC, there is no reason for my to buy it for the console.  L Here are some of the reasons I USED to buy consoles: Console Specific Games:  We just went over that.  Back in the day they had their own games, but now for the most part any game I want to play I can get for my PC.  On my PC it will look better, it will have mods, and I can play it for years to come (more on that later).  The occasional console exclusive title isn't enough to change that. Social Play:  The other nice thing about playing console games used to be the social aspect.  Having some friends come over after school and playing together (ie the 4 way deathmatches on Goldeneye, taking turns trying to beat levels in Mega Man 2).  But that was before broadband, that was before Battle.net, that was before I was almost 30.  This is the one corner of the market where Nintendo still has the advantage.  If I do want to have some friends come over we are going to do something like play drunken Wii bowling.  Now there are some sports and fighting games out there that I guess could still make the argument for in-person social play, but I am not a particularly huge fan of those genres, and I don't think they are enough reason to buy a several hundred dollar console. Now the disadvantages of consoles: Backwards Compatibility:  Apparently the Xbox One will not only not play any Xbox or 360 games, but will not even play XBLA games.  I am lucky enough that I snagged one of the old PS3s that can play PS2 games, and I dread the day it dies.  If I spend my money on a game, I want to be able to play that game years down the line if I feel like it, without having to dig some old console out of my closet and pray it still works.  If I buy a game for my PC I know that I can play it anytime I want on any PC I own for the forseeable future.  A PC pretty much has unlimited backwards compatibility.  Even some old DOS game you may have lying around, you may need to fiddle with it a little, but you can probably get it to work.  If I buy a game on Steam today, I am confident that I can play that game anytime I want regardless of how often I upgrade or replace my PC. Mods:  A relatively new aspect, but an important one nonetheless is mods.  Mods for PC games have really taken off.  There are mods for everything.  And some of them are really fun.  Not having mods certainly isn't a dealbreaker, but it is certainly a nice option to have. Upgradeable:  I can upgrade my PC.  I frequently do.  That's usually where my tax return goes each year.  As powerful as a new console is at launch day, technology just moves too fast for a locked in system to succeed.  10 years ago this was less of an issue, but unless the PS4 has the ability to swap out it's graphics card or add more RAM, I just don't see it competing with a PC. Back to the Xbox One.  I didn't get into Kinect.  When I am playing a video game it's because I want to sit down and be lazy.  If I want to stand up and move around I will go outside.  That's actually the reason I was less then sold on the Wii at first, but that grew on me.  The Wii motion controls are kind of fun without requiring you to dance around your living room.  So a new, better, more precise, slightly creepy Kinect has no appeal to me. Getting back into the backwards compatibility, I think that's a huge negative.  I am not one of them, but a lot of people out there are really invested into their XBLA library.  And XBLA games, with typically shorter, fun gameplay, I think lend themselves to replay-ability more then big money AAA console titles.  I like Fable, I beat it, it was a fun game, I am never going to play it again.  A game like Castle Crashers on the other hand...  Also it just doesn't feel right.  Backwards compatibility with physical games can be justified.  Different console architecture, some things may not be compatible.  And it wouldn't surprise me if in the relatively near future they start adding Xbox One playable versions of original Xbox and Xbox360 games to XBLA.  Sucks having to buy the same game twice, but understandable.  But they can't do that with XBLA games, not without pissing a lot of people off.  Having to pay to download a game you already paid to download?  While technically it makes sense, current gen XBLA titles may not be compatible with Xbox One hardware for the exact same reason that 360 games aren't compatible with Xbox One hardware, it just feels wrong. The home media center aspects of the Xbox One are cool, in theory.  I am not upset at Microsoft for adding them.  They just don't appeal to me.  While they are cool, they're not anything super revolutionary.  Their not anything I NEED to have.  It's a lot of things that Tivo an Smart TVs are already doing, or will be doing shortly.  And as a member of the ever growing minority of people that just don't watch cable most of them are things I would never use.  I watch Netflix and Hulu.  I won't pay for a cable package that includes HBO, but I would probably pay for some kind of streaming HBO service.  I think that's the direction media is going in general.  Maybe the Xbox One will make it easier to consume media that way, maybe, but it's not presented itself as a device you NEED to have to do so.  DVRS and multi tuners don't affect that.  I'm not pissed like a lot of the internet, but I am thoroughly un-intrigued. I can see how some people with money to burn, who watch a lot of tv, are possible really into sports, may end up buying it.  But it doesn't seem to be targeted to me, the gamer. So, to reiterate, I have no desire to spend $399 on a console that only does things my PC already does better.  Plain and simple.  Now if they come out with just some ridiculously fantastic Xbox exclusive titles, and they drop the price, and let me port over XBLA titles, then maybe?  I don't plan on buying either console, though the chances of Sony changing my mind with some really interesting exclusive titles (maybe some Final Fantasy games which I can never say no to) are slightly higher then Microsoft, but still unlikely.  Just the fact that it's a new console is no longer enough reason for me justify the purchase.  A new console has to bring something truly unique to the table that a PC just cannot do. Until then I have no problem running an HDMI cable to my tv and playing all the Steam, and I don't see that changing anytime soon.

item.title: White Collar
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
I LOVE White Collar. Probably my favorite tv show currently airing. But I will be the first to admit it is getting a little repetitive and at some times even sloppy. The whole 'end each season on some kind of a cliffhanger just to wrap up everything up and return to the status quo 15 minutes into the next season premier' thing is getting old. I would have liked a few episodes of Neal on the run internationally in season 4 before returning. Maybe a few episodes of Peter in prison before they find a way to clear his name in this season. But nope. Despite the fact that in season 3 Peter was fully advocating for Neal to be released, now he's back to not trusting him and obsessively checking his anklet? Why? Because that's the dynamic of the show and the writers seem to be following the 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' motto as closely as possible.
Neal should be off anklet by now. It made sense the first season or two but now it's just a poorly used gimmick. It has no impact on the show, we all know that Neal could run anytime he wants anyways. The tension it was designed to create just no longer applies. Better to have him off anklet but still coming into work at the FBI every day of his own volition, show how he has grown as a person as a result of the father/son relationship he's formed with Peter over the show. And maybe show that a little bit of Neal has rubbed off on Peter as well, make him a little more apt to bend the law in the name of justice when necessary.
As much as I love the show, if they don't use this season to shake things up I may lose interest at not return for season 6.

item.title: Hello World
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: Hello World, and welcome to my blog. I guess this is where I should tell you a little about me and why I am making this site. The tl;dr version is simple: I want to be a professional software developer, and I am hoping this site helps with that. The longer version is a little more complicated. Guess I should start at the beginning? I was always a pretty smart kid. I was placed in the program for gifted kids way back in Elementary school. In High School I was mostly Honors and Advanced Placement (including AP Computer Science) classes. But what I had in brains usually wasn't enough to compensate for my complete lack of focus. I was diagnosed with ADHD pretty young, but never treated for it. My mother didn't want to "drug up" her son, and to be honest I wasn't too keen on the idea of taking pills every day either. So I ended up spending most of High School skipping class, chasing girls and only showing up on test day. I never had any clear direction or focus and my poor single mother spent all of her time and energy keeping a roof over our heads. There wasn't much left over to discipline me and keep me in line. After I graduated High School that didn't really change. Still smart, still lacking any semblance of direction or focus. I always had a lot of people telling me that I could "do anything I put my mind to", no one actually telling me what that should be. I had absolutely no idea what I wanted to do with my life. I ended up enrolling in The University of Advancing Computer Technology's B.A. in Game Design program because, well why not. I liked video games and making them for a living sounded like it would be a blast. Plus, while I wasn't sure what I wanted to do, I knew that staying in Alaska wasn't part of it, so doing the smart thing and just going to the University of Alaska, getting a B.S. in CS on that sweet low in-state tuition was out of the question. In retrospect, not my brightest decision. Fast forward a few years and I graduated with a decent amount of debt and not a lot in the way of job skills. Sure the degree was fun. A lot of the classes were interesting, but they weren't all that practical. One Intro to Programming class that covered less than the AP Computer Science class I took in High School, a few basic 3D Animation classes, and then just a lot of design and theory. Not enough to get an entry level programming or animation job, at a game studio or elsewhere. During college I paid the bills with IT related work; started at Geeksquad, moved on to help-desk here, network admin there, etc. After college I was able to use that experience, as well as my 'design' background, to land the gig I have now. I currently work for TherapySites in a customer support/helpdesk/some basic front end design role. Basically we have a custom in-house CMS, customers call or email in when they have problems, and I either walk them through it or do it for them. Sometimes it's a request that our CMS can't actually do, so I get to dig in and code it manually, but that's relatively rare. It's not a bad job all things considered. It's paid the bills so far, it's a remote job so the commute is fantastic, and I like the people I work with. Met my best friend through it. But I've definitely reached my ceiling with them. That combined with a few health scares in my immediate family last year made it apparent that neither I, nor the people I care about, are getting any younger. I spent all of my youth telling my mom that I was going to be rich when I grew up and I was going to buy her a "big house with a swimming pool." Recent events have made it clear that I need to get on that. Luckily being an alumni of UAT means I can audit any of their classes for free. I have been auditing my way through their CS degree program (online) and I feel like I am to the point where I have the fundamentals down. I have a fairly solid grasp of both Java and C++, along with the 'core' CS fundamentals like data structures, algorithms and software design principles. In addition to that I've supplemented it with a lot of self study through things like Coursera, CodeCademy and Treehouse. I'm not 'done' (not that I think one can ever truly be done learning) yet, but really close. Right now I am focusing on creating this portfolio, getting some things up on GitHub (most of the things I have done so far have either been homework for a class I was auditing or a class from Coursera, not things I would want to put online for anyone to cheat from, and working full time in addition to auditing classes hasn't left a lot of free time for personal projects), and really solidifying my understanding of Algorithms. UAT's online program consist of one 5-week class at a time. I feel as if their one 5-week Algorithms class only scratched the surface. I'm finishing up my way through Algorithms, 4th Ed and it's associated Coursera Princeton courses, and will probably take the Coursera Stanford Algorithms class as well next time it is offered. I'm also currently enrolled in Coursera's Android Specialization. So I decided to start this blog as a way to track my progress, talk about what I've learned, and keep me focused. When I have to write regular blog posts about the progress I have made, I will be much more motivated to ensure I have something to talk about in said posts. Wish me luck!

item.title: Want to learn to program? Read a book!
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: I've basically been teaching myself computer science. Yes I have been auditing classes from my Alma Mater, but even that's been mainly self teaching. Since it's through their online program and there are no video lectures or anything, most of the classes consist entirely of an assigned textbook, assigned reading from that textbook, assigned homework (usually from that textbook), a forum for the students to post in, and a weekly 'lecture' that is almost always nothing more than a powerpoint of what are basically cliff notes from the assigned reading. Now I am not sure why a university that costs tens of thousands of dollars a year and has 'Advancing Technology' in it's name can't manage to put up YouTube videos of their lectures for the online students, but that's a complaint for another post. Back to the point, I've basically been teaching myself. UAT has done a decent job of telling me what I needed to learn and in what order, but I'm still teaching myself. During this I've read textbooks, done the CodeCademy thing and paid subscription tutorials like TreeHouse. You want to know which of those, by far, I have learned the most from? I'll give you three guesses. CodeCademy is great for someone to dip their toe in to learn IF they want to learn more about programming. Tutorials like TreeHouse are great for practice and for reinforcing concepts. But if you really want to learn about something then read a good meaty book on it. The problem with most tutorials, ranging from posts on a blog to something with a little more production value like TreeHouse, is while they may tell you all the steps you need to do a thing, they are usually pretty poor at explaining why you are doing those steps. When you're done doing a tutorial that teaches you how to do a thing you may know how to do that thing, but if that's the only exposure you've had to that subject then chances are you can't take what you learned in the tutorial on it's own and do anything else with it. You want to be a Ruby developer? Great. But don't go just do all of the Ruby Monk or Codeschool Ruby courses and think that's all you need. Go pick yourself up a copy of Learn To Program and marathon through it in a few days (It's only 190 pages yet still manages to touch on all of the concepts you need to know to get started) and if you like what you read then move on to Programming Ruby. Then after you've done that, by all means go do all of the online video tutorials. I promise you'll get a lot more from them if in the back your mind you know WHY the instructor is telling you to do those things, as opposed to just following along on autopilot. Online tutorials are great for reinforcing things you've already learned, maybe inspiring you to do something in a way you hadn't done before, generally helping your brain 'connect the dots'. But at the end of the day, for all of our advanced technology, the single best way to learn a thing is to read a good solid book on that thing. I have a Safari Books Online subscription and it's the best investment I have ever made. That being said I am grandfathered in to a $9/mo 5 books at a time plan. When I signed up (if I remember correctly) they had a 5 book, a 10 book, and an unlimited plan. Now on their site they only seem to mention the unlimited plan for $40/mo, which at that price it might just be more economical to rent the books, or buy them used on Amazon and then re-sell them when you're done. They might also still have the lower tier plans, but maybe it's one of this things you have to sign up for the free trial, then try and cancel when that's over and they throw it out there to convince you to still subscribe (like when you try and cancel Sirius XM and they respond by giving you 6 months for like, $1). If anyone tries that and it works, be sure to leave it in a comment.

item.title: A lifelong Windows guy buys a Macbook?
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
I've recently had a case of eating my own words.
I've always thought Apple products were all flash, no substance. Could never see why anyone would want to buy one. Then I went and got myself a Macbook Pro...and I love it.
I have a Windows desktop because I like to build my machines and tweak my hardware. I'm a PC gamer. I regularly swap and overclock video cards, add more ram, move my fans around trying to maximize airflow. My first computer was a Gateway my mom bought for me, every one I've had since I built myself.
But when it came for me to replace my last laptop I opted for a 13" MBP. And, as far as laptops go, it's a dream. It's the only trackpad I've ever actually enjoyed using. I recently used it as my daily driver when I was visiting family for the holidays for 3 weeks and I didn't have to use my wireless mouse once. The screen is gorgeous, obviously. As a web developer, terminal is super helpful. Now I can test things on Safari if I need to. I would also like to get into iOS development at some point so Xcode was a must.
Build wise it is by far the nicest laptop I've ever owned. That being said, I've never owned a 'premium' laptop before. In the past almost all of my computer budget has gone to my beastly desktop, with whatever left over going towards a low end, possibly refurbished "I just need something to browse the internet and maybe write a little code on" laptop. I know that for the same $1300 I could have gotten a 'premium' Windows laptop with higher specs, even a higher resolution screen, but that's the Apple tax for you.
OS wise, it's a wash. They both have some really good things, and they both have some really infuriating things. Terminal is great. Finder is horrible. I actually don't mind Launchpad while I hate Windows 8 Live Tiles (though that could just be because I am so used to Start doing a thing that I just don't like it no longer doing that thing). So to each their own in that regard. Obviously I am still an OSX noob, but it does feel like OSX deserves the "easier to use but not as powerful/customizable" reputation I've heard over the years. If I could only choose one, I would go with Windows just for that reason, but the next computer I buy my mom will be an Apple. Click and drag to install is right about her maximum technical ability.
I don't think I'll ever buy a Mac desktop. The iMac still makes no sense to me. A desktop that uses laptop parts? The Mac Pro is nice to look at, but WAY overpriced. And I'm a diehard Android fan, way too invested in the ecosystem to change now. But I could see myself only buying Macbooks from now on for my laptops.

item.title: I am a horrible typist
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: I use a weird, hover my hands over the keyboard and use primarily my pointer and index fingers to type style of typing. Kind of like hunt-and-peck without the hunt part. It works decently well. When I am on a good streak and I am typing something simple (ie not code) I can probably break 60 wpm. But when I try and type the "proper" way, the fingers on home-row, all that jazz, my typing speed goes to crap. I never took a typing class in High School. I've just always used computers and developed my own typing style that worked for me. But after getting frustrated with having to look at the keyboard occasionally to re-orientate my hands and about how inefficient my typing sometimes becomes when I was trying to type code I thought that maybe I should learn the proper way. So I signed up for a Typing.com account, did the lessons, and then remembered why I never followed through on learning it before. It's incredibly painful for me. The reason I keep my hands hovering over the keyboard, slightly to the sides, instead on the keyboard on home row at all times is because it causes my right wrist to have horrible pains. Now this is my mousing wrist and it's given me trouble for years. It used to hurt all the time. A while back I took to wearing a brace on it at night and using this mouse for all my non-gaming mousing needs, and that worked for the most part. No more constant wrist pain. But trying to do the home-row thing still aggravates it. According to Typing.com, typing the 'proper' way, I am averaging an abysmal 27wpm. And my right wrist is killing me. I have been trying to force myself to do it, thinking maybe it was just an adjustment period, but it's not looking so hot. I know this isn't critical. Being a speed typist isn't necessary to being a good programmer. But I'm sure it helps. And I am worried I will go into an interview and make a fool of myself with my modified quick hunt-and-peck style of typing one day. I've thought about surgery, but everything I've read tells me that's only a last resort. So I am going to try doing a lesson or two on Typing.com every day for another week or so, see if the pain fades. If it doesn't I may have to start looking into investing in a nice ergonomic, or even a split, keyboard. It really feels like it wouldn't be nearly as much of an issue if my hands were farther apart. While I love my Razor mechanical keyboard, it may be time to retire it for some other options.

item.title: Will Code For Food
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded:
I've decided to make a job board, Will Code For Food. The premise is this (copied from the 'about' page on that site): === Tired of seeing ‘junior’ positions that want 3-5 years of experience in 9 different stacks, some of which aren’t even 5 years old? Sick of wading through hundreds of job postings looking for one that you, as a new developer, are qualified for? Well so was I, so I decided to create this site. This job board is only for jobs, internships and apprenticeships for people still in college, new graduated, recently self taught, and anyone else who wants a developer job but has no work experience. It’s free to search, and for the time being free to post. I fit strongly into the category of someone who would use this site. Currently looking to get my first real developer job. After spending another evening looking through job boards and not finding much that someone with no actual work experience should realistically apply for, I got frustrated and decided to throw this site up. I grabbed the domain name and got to work. Phase 1 – Right now this site is built using WordPress and WP Job Manager. Functionality is fairly limited. You can browse jobs and apply to them by following the link. It’s not what I envision, but I wanted to get something up ASAP. Phase 2 – The next phase will be a complete job board built from scratch. Partly because I think this will be fun to build, and partly because I really want to customize it for developers. Features I have in mind for phase 2 include:
  • Complete job-seeker profiles.
  • The ability to sign up with and integrate your GitHub profile.
  • The ability to apply to jobs directly.
  • The ability to display some of your accomplishments, such as your HackerRank or Project Euler scores.
  • The ability to display your progress in things like The Odin Project or Code School.
  • A blog with submission from hiring managers and industry professionals full of advice on getting that first job.
  • Anything else I come up with.
=== Like I mentioned in that blurb, right now it's just Wordpress. Not that there's anything wrong with Wordpress, it's what I use for this blog and despite some 'pro' developers looking down on it, I still happen to think it's a solid CMS. That being said I do plan on eventually building a custom solution for it. Not that I think it will be better than Wordpress, but because I think it would be a really god learning exercise and a great addition to my portfolio. I have no idea how successfull it will be, not because I don't think it's a good idea, but I really have no idea how to market or properly monetize it against the insane amount of job boards already out there. But who knows, it could take off and running it could be my full time job one day. Take a look and drop me a line if you like what you see, and on the off chance you're hiring go ahead and post a job!

item.title: Focusing on JavaScript
item.dc:creator: taylor
item.content:encoded: I've decided that, for the time being, I am going to focus most of my web related studying on JavaScript (and it's various libraries). I was working through The Odin Project, which is definitely a great project and a great curriculum, but it's primarily Ruby?rails focused. Not that there's anything wrong with Ruby, that was my first exposure to it and I can certainly see why people like it. But coming from a C++/Java background, I just find the syntax of JavaScript to be much more intuitive. Curly brackets, semicolons, all that jazz. I'm sure I will revisit The Odin Project at some point, as well as Ruby in general, but I don't want to spread myself too thin. I think the biggest hurdle of self-teaching is getting distracted, is not knowing where to start or where to go next. You start learning one thing, hear about something else, jump to that, etc. Eventually you know the first 10% of a bunch of different topics, and not enough to actually create anything in any of them. So Ruby on Rails is going on the back burner for now. Right now I'm still juggling learning JavaScript for web dev, keeping up to date on Java for Algorithms (Coursera), and in a few weeks the second section of the Android Specialization starts. Plus the classes from UAT I am auditing. I was supposed to be auditing Compilers starting this week, but the class was cancelled (not enough enrollment?) so I have a breather from that for the next 5 weeks. Throwing Ruby in the mix now is probably a bad idea. So getting back to JavaScript. I am already decently familiar with it. I've used it for some basic stuff at my job for a while now. Like I mentioned most of the syntax for it is pretty intuitive given my background. I've done the CodeCademy JavaScript and jQuery courses (which were a little dry but they got the job done). I've done some of the JavaScript courses through Treehouse the free intro JavaScript and jQuery classes from CodeSchool. I actually really enjoyed the Codeschool ones and I was planning on subscribing to them and continuing down the track until I remember that Udacity has some as part of their Front End Web Developer Nanodegree. I like Udacity, I think their online platform is great and all of the classes from them I've dabbled in have had really charismatic instructors. I do think their time estimates are a little off. For example, their JavaScript Basics course is supposed to take three weeks, but it's only about 2 hours or so worth of videos. I did it in an evening. I mean, I'm not exactly a beginner, but still... The other classes I've taken from them had similarly generous estimates. Right now I am just marathoning through the classes themselves. I'm not actually signed up for the 'Nanodegree' program. While I like what they are trying to accomplish, I'm just not sold that $200/mo is a justifiable price when all of the actual lectures and coursework is completely free. Granted it's still a helluva lot cheaper than college. Now according to the FAQ you can complete it as fast as you want. The next enrollment opens on March 4th, by then I should have had more than enough time to complete all of the actual classes in it, so I may enroll for a month, just long enough to submit all of my projects and earn the certificate. We'll see how I feel in March. And, holding to my philosophy that books are the best way to learn, I picked up a copy of Node.js, MongoDB, and AngularJS Web Development (Developer's Library) through Safari Books and have been reading through that. Not too deep in but so far it seems like a decently written book. I doubt it will make me an expert on any of those topics, but it should give me a broad enough overview of all of them and how they interact that I can then dive deeper with more specific books and tutorials.
